reviewText:
I am fairly confident that Payday: The Heist is one of the best games I've ever played. At its heart, it's a cops and robbers game that feels a bit like Left 4 Dead, except instead of navigating on a linear path through multiple maps, you take control of and dominate a single map, and you only play as the robbers, not the cops. Featuring a diverse set of maps, a cool leveling system that encourages player experimentation and mobility, and generally just being amazing, Payday: The Heist is the single greatest co-op experience I've ever had. I think it's better than Left 4 Dead, to be quite honest.

Would you like to know how many things I would change about the game?

Zero things. The answer is Zero things. Because there are Zero things I would change. Actually, come to think of it, I would change one thing: the game's leveling curve is a bit 'off,' and newer players have a harder time enjoying the game until about level twenty or so, but that's a problem easily solved. Oh, don't get me wrong, I'd totally be up for adding new features--maybe better stealth, more customized ammo, more maps with more unique behaviors, and stuff like that--but the fact is, the game is just pretty awesome as it is.

You can sprint sideways.
You can use fake dummy turrets to keep crowds down while you steal a man's blood in the PC-exclusive Mercy Hospital level.
You can sprint backwards.
You can spend thirty-three minutes drilling into a secret vault hidden away in the game's first level.
You can yell at Alex for being a terrible, terrible crane driver.
YOU CAN SPRINT IN ALL DIRECTIONS AND THE BRENNER IS AMAZING AND THE STRYK IS LIKE PEW PEW PEW AND MY LOVE FOR THIS GAME IS SO INTENSE YOU DON'T EVEN...

All of the game's features work well together. Only one of the maps--Heat Street--is bad. It's a co-op game. It's not a solo game. You play with other people, and you'll have a blast. I've bought fifteen or twenty copies for friends now.

EDIT: Hey, just because I've bought copies for friends doesn't mean I'm going to buy a copy for you. A) I can't afford to do this anymore, and B) if you're a person who friended me at random, why would you expect me to buy you a game?

reviewText:
Payday: The Heist is a first person shooter game developed by Overkill Software and published by Sony Entertainment. The game was released in October 2011 on PC, after being released on PS3. The game is owned on Steam by over four million players due to its regularity being on sale.

The gameplay is based around completing heists with a party of four people including you. This can be done either in a single player environment, or up to 4 player co-op online. The heists can consist of the classic bank jobs, right the way to the complete extreme of extracting blood from a highly classified patient. You play the role of one of the four main characters in the game, Dallas, Chains, Wolf or Hoxton.  Each member of the team can use a variety of different weapons, you are able to select your load out before jumping into a heist, so once you get to know what is needed to be done on each heist, you can select what to use accordingly. Each of the missions starts off in a stealth style mission, where you have to disable security camera, turning off alarm systems etc. Whether you complete these tasks successfully or not without being seen will determine how the rest of the heist will carry out.  These starting missions are done really well, and you will be fully immersed since most of them have you sneaking around a pitch black building trying to out manoeuvre the guards. A lot of the missions also come with the added obstacle of civilians – these are crucial in any of the heists as you can keep them hostage and use them as bargaining trades should one of your other team mates be captured by the police too.

Whilst you can spend a good portion of the game in stealth and hopefully not being noticed, a good portion of the game will also be spent with you going all guns blazing as you attempt to fend off an almost endless stream of enemy police and SWAT.  The gunplay in Payday really well done. All of the guns feel as powerful as you would expect, and the choice of weapons is pretty big when compared to other FPS games.  Ammo does become a problem with your primary weapon since you’ll be shooting this off constantly at points, but can be easily countered by the abundance of pickups of ammo off dead enemies.

Even though Payday is almost four years old at this point, it is still a really good looking game, especially when you ramp up the resolution to 4k. Originally I thought the game was made using the Source engine due to the familiarities in the graphics with the likes of Half Life 2 and Left 4 Dead, but the game is made using an engine called Diesel (made by GRIN, who are now defunct unfortunately). There are a couple of textures which are very low resolution which is a shame, but I can forgive this a bit given that a lot of the levels are actually fairly big, so this must have been done to reduce the need for loading screens.  The game has a really good ragdoll simulation too, when you are mowing down the enemies, they don’t just die in a normal fall to the floor fashion, each death is individually animated depending on where/how they were shot, which adds to the originality slightly.

Payday is fully voice acted and done really well at that; the game is almost narrated by what seems to be someone behind the scenes instructing your team on what to do next on the heist. You’ll get remarks back from the rest of the team in responses to objectives being completed and you’ll also get a lot of radio chatter when you are in firefights with the police too.

This is a really hard game. The first couple of heists come with the option to play them on easy mode; these must really be the games tutorial since they can be completed without any real problems; yet once you reach the third or fourth mission, the difficulty takes a big ramp up and you’ll actually find yourself either failing missions from not completing objectives, or because you have died or been taken into custody. I had to replay each of the last few stages of the game multiple times before I was able to successfully complete the heists. Even though the ramp in difficulty felt really harsh at the time; I began to enjoy the game even more because of it; because it’s not just as simple as a “get in and out” job, it forces you to plan your every move, and you will tread with caution around every corner because of the unknown ambush that awaits you. The game also has another two difficulty levels to be played on, Hard and overkill mode – these are modes which should not even be considered when playing on single player because you will not stand a chance. I tried the overkill mode out and it is just absolute carnage. I will definitely be asking friends to join in a game to give this mode a proper try out.

Whilst all of the missions have the same key objective, and there is really only one way to complete said objective, it can lead to a little repetitive gameplay. The game does however try to counteract that by adding a little bit of randomness into the stages by shaking things up a bit; such as locations the locations of key civilians that you need to keep hostage, meaning you still have to go searching through the whole building to find them rather than rushing to the one place. Each of the levels has some form of random element to it which is nice to see, since you will be playing the same six or seven heists over and over again.

I have put about twenty hours into Payday: The Heist so far and see no end in sight for it at the moment. There is still a really active multiplayer scene if you want to just find pick up groups with randommers, but I would highly recommend playing this with a bunch of friends on Skype to get the full experience out of it. The added levels of difficulty also adds plenty of replay ability too; meaning you will not run out of interesting content for a long while with this title. The game does have one piece of DLC which includes new weapons and two new heists, which is a worthwhile piece of DLC.

The game is also extremely technically sound too; I was able to play on 4k resolution with all of the graphic options maxed out and I was still able to hit the heights of 160 FPS, so this is one of the best optimized games out there at the moment.  Keyboard and mouse is recommended to play with, given the FPS nature.

Overall, Payday: The Heist is an extremely good game; one that I am surprised it has taken me so long to play, and one that I will certainly be keeping installed on my machine because of the high replay ability factor. The game is also very cheaply priced at £10,99 – but like I said at the start, the game is always going on sale, and most of the time it is for 90% off; at that price, is it an absolute no brainer to pick it up – you may as well pick up the four pack for yourself and friends whilst you are at it.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText: When I got PAYDAY 1 on a steam sale, I didn't play it till my friends got it. And now it's one of my favorite games. Even though PAYDAY 2 is out and I find that game really fun, I still come back to this game because the 2 games have 2 different play styles. PAYDAY 2 is more realisic and strategic, while PAYDAY 1 feels like it's more Left 4 Dead or Mass Effect 3 multiplyer. It also feels more fast paced, sending larger waves of enemies in maps that offer poor cover causing the player to use their unlimited sprint, and 0 reduction on your speed due to the armor you must wear to survive, to dodge and return fire on maps that contain both close and long range encounters. Both of the PAYDAY games are on my list of best games I've ever played.\n\nI highly recommend these games.

reviewText:
Imagine Left 4 Dead except you're shooting cops instead of zombies.

There's a level progression system in the game just like in the sequel, but you don't have to worry about any of the RPG ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t elements, just level up and spend points. Imagine more like Killing Floor where playing the game gives you progress  on each class. You can grind it out to get there faster, but that'll go against what the game's pushing you towards.

People say it's comparable to Payday 2 in that they're the same characters and world, etc. They're wrong. The game is paced completely differently: heists aren't meant to be quick in-and-out situations, they're long, gruelling marathons you have to push through. They also don't function on an all or nothing" reward system. If you fail right at the end
recommended: you still get money (experience) for every objective you completed along the way. It's not as rage inducing as ♥♥♥♥ing up a Big Bank stealth right as you're opening the vault

reviewText:
Payday The Heist is an amazing game that you should not buy for full price. It goes on sale for five dollars at least four times a year, and then you'll probably be able to grab the Wolf Pack for 99 cents, which is almost necessary to feel like you got the full game.

If you've played Payday 2, I need to warn you that the two games are fundamentally similar, but that's where it stops.  Payday:The Heist does not have as many mechanics as Payday 2; you will always be a speedy, slightly tanky glass cannon who is in danger of running out of ammo and must take cover to survive prolonged assaults. But this gives the game a tension and skill ceiling that really augments the gameplay.

Payday:The Heist is much more scripted than Payday 2; in general you are playing the heists the way the developers intended and some may find that repetitive. But the heists are SO MUCH BETTER than in Payday 2! Nothing in Payday 2 comes close to the sheer creativity and versatility of what every heist in Payday:The Heist throws at you. It's very tough to get bored when a single heist involves you visiting a hospital, restraining all the civilians, impersonating doctors, breaking into quarantine, drawing and purifying blood samples, restarting the power to get the elevator working, crashing into the morgue and commandeering an ambulance for the escape.

It's really a kickass game and you're missing out if you don't try it.

reviewText: Started to play this game without too much expectations, since it has only a limited number of maps. I certainly didn't expect that this game would be fun even after 1k hours. Admittedly this game has lots of flaws, but in part that's what makes it such a great game. The random elements in the game, spawns, enemy pathing and to a lesser extend the objectives, make the game unpredictable and failure is always around the corner. Unlike some Co-op PvE games out there, you actually have to play tactical and watch your HP (using shoot and cover") to complete the heists on the higher difficulties (and for beginners even on the lower ones). Failing to do so will get you punished (although you can get away with it to some extend when playing with a VERY good team) and in all likeliness gets your character killed.\n\nBesides the satisfaction of beating the game on the highest difficulties with a good team
date: you can basically make it as hard on yourself as you want. If the default difficulties aren't enough
recommended: install DorHUD and play on an even higher difficulty with even more spawns (and yes
hoursPlayed: this makes a huge difference). Seeing all those helmets flying is a reason to keep playing the game and there's always room for improvement: more kills per minute
voteText: better accuracy
helpfulPercent: fewer downs
votesHelpful: faster completion of the heist or just competing to be the best in the stats at the end of the heist when playing with other players
votesTotal: which can make for incredibly fun games ;).\n\nThe only downsides of this game is the crappy bots (although this can be seen as a factor that makes the game harder) and the fact that there are quite a few cheaters. reviewText:
Have you ever dreamed of robbing a bank, jewerly store or stealing a well-secured precious object?
Almost everyone do that sooner or later, in FPS PAYDAY™ The Heist you can try it out either with AI or up to 4 players in cooperative mode. The game brings you to every detail of heist, from entering target facility to escaping the police if necessary, which can be very tricky.

I enjoyed FPS side of the game, shooting a lot of cops, whose raids are really common and after a while you will be surprised how many police forces are in the city ready to dying trying a heist of 4 robbers. On the other side defence is not a problem at all, the difficulties start with a lack of ammo - that's what I suppose as the biggest obstacle. I recommend this game for coop gameplay, with a bunch of friends it is really entertaining, but in singleplayer mode the game is almost unplayable, because of the uselessness of bots.

7/10

reviewText:
This game, I would say, is better than it's sequel in many ways.
1-it's more polished. sure this game isn't beautiful or complex, but it has far fewer glitches, bugs, it's more balanced and is just generally more, finished.
2-i personally find far more enjoyment from it's heists, which last a decent amount of time and are very satisfying to pulloff, aside from some lack of replayability without friends.
3-the game seems, well, fair. it's balanced, the cops can both put up a strong fight but also don't take extortionate amounts of bullets to kill and in no heist are all odd's against you.
4-it's cheaper, easier to run and more unique, in it's own action-movie homage way.
what i will say that is bad is that it's no beauty pageant winner and has quite a rustic style of fighting, and isn't entirely quick to connect people to a lobby and could've had more done for it overall.

I recommend this, especially if it's on sale, and don't mind that this review might've been a TL;DR.

I dream this game will be updated by competent developers... but is not. Huge potential wasted.

reviewText:
Once you start up Payday you can instantly see the resemblance to Heat, a Michael Mann-directed action movie. Every level is about a heist - you go in, you grab the money and you get out. In the meantime, dozens (if not hundreds) of cops are hurled against you. The 4 of you must work together to survive the level.

Every level has sections. You always have to do something before you can advance. For instance, you are in a hospital where your job is to steal blood samples. However, in order to proceed to the section of the special patients you need to cut through a door with a saw. These machines usually require activation. Still, you need to remain close by to see if they stop so that you can start them up again.The waves of enemies get more frequent and dangerous. Same goes for the bank mission: you cut through the safe, but oh wait, you need some thermite to be able to enter the vault.

Payday is one of those games where if you complete the levels you have pretty much seen everything. BUT! You have new weapons and other equipment to unlock once you level up. This so-called reputation level goes up till 193 and the higher level you are the more money you need to achieve the next level.

Essentially, the replayability goes along the road Killing Floor has. Higher levels make you stronger (due to the new equipment) so you are able to pick a higher difficulty and replay the heists once more. Or die trying as this game is VERY difficult. Even on normal difficulty you will sweat to see the end of the road. And then you have at least 200 achievements waiting to be unlocked. :)

PAYDAY is a fun game. If you have a lot of time on your hands and you like farming" this is for you.

"

reviewText:
Payday is one-of-a-kind, at least for me it is. When I first saw the clown masks, I could only think to myself - The Dark Knight. As it turns out, it is like the Dark Knight but without the Batman. It is the 'heist' that starts at the beginning of the movie. Stealing from a loaded bank while fighting off an unlimited number of police officers and SWAT is hardly an easy task. The money they said, would let me buy Steam games as far as the eye can see. I went for it. That's when the fire nation attacked. As I leveled up my reputation, I remembered the one thing that could save me, my ammo pack, so I laid it down and went to town. Pow pow pow, the SWAT went down and I escaped with my pockets full of cash. But alas, the bus driver had to end my streak, leaving me with a mouth full of gas.

There are other levels too might I mention.

Obligatory score: 7/10

reviewText:
Difficulty: Very Hard
The Bottom Line: Good Multiplayer/ Fair
Score: 6.0

Note: This Game Been Tried Out And Reviewed In Offline Mode or On Another Steam Account And Or Consoles.

Payday: The Heist is definitely one of the best downloadable titles.

Payday the Heist developed by Overkill Software and released in 2011 is a coop based first person shooter falling in the same sub genre as Left For Dead. Payday essentially takes the gameplay elements from Left Four Dead and instead of a zombie setting, the game has a crime mob atmosphere

This game has been compared by the trolls as a Left 4 Dead clone
date:
which is horribly false. It actually does have some reliable comparisons about each games'

The premise of this game is great.
You get to embark on only six various heist missions and complete different tasks.

You get to play with four of your Co-op friends and there is plenty of teamwork and coordination involved.

However, this game is insanely unbalanced.There's almost an infinite enemy respawn, There is a ton of upgrades for instance, which comprise new guns, less recoil, better accuracy, more damage, better armor, mines, new accessories, cuffs, etc

You can also take up to three hostages (for each member of your team, unless you exchange your ammo bag for three cuffs). But you cannot even move these hostages, you basically place them on the ground, tie them up and pray that the cops won't get to them, because if they do, the time for negotiation and your subsequent release from custody gets extended beyond 3 minutes. And let me tell you, once one of your team members gets caught, there is very little chance that the other 3 members will be able to hold out for the entire 3 minutes. So the whole hostage thing is moot, just ignore them, or kill them so they don't get in the way

Every frustration that I have described so far has to do with normal difficulty. I cannot even imagine what's it like playing on Hard or Overkill

I honestly have no idea what the devs were thinking with this game. Why throw that many suicidal cops and swat team members? It is so unrealistic. All they do is use smoke occasionally, send in one member with a shield or taser gun. They basically make suicidal attacks like the Japanese in WW2, so you get to mow them down and get shot at the same time. When you get shot at, your screen jerks around, your aim gets messed up and your screen gets red - the typical FPS tricks

ll they had to do was lessen the amount of enemies, make enemies harder to kill, make mini tasks more interesting and add a fluid cover system. However, most of the mini tasks that you need to complete do not have any meaningful cover available, so you basically run around like an idiot and try to kill as many enemies as possible

Overall: The game basically crosses over the line many times over where the frustrations pile up and it's not fun anymore.  The game gets repetitive and tedious pretty fast. other than that. multiplayer is fair enough but it gets boring after a while.

reviewText:
This game is all about killing 'cops' or 'sprites' depending how you look at things.

In fact I actually have met a real live cop that plays this...

Dead set! True! The conversation in game went something like this...

Kyzka: So what you do for work?
Cpt Bob: I'm a cop in real life.
Kyzka: What? Seriously?
Cpt Bob: Yeah.
Kyzka: Isn't that like living a double life or something? A cop playing a video game where your a bad guy that kills cops for a living...
Cpt Bob: It depends, I view it more as im in training learning all the things I should not do.
Kyzka: Is that why your forever in donut shops?
Cpt Bob: Exactly we try our best to arrive several days after the incident that way this sort of killing cop thing never happens...

In game Cops pretty much arrive in waves the millisecond you start to look at someone the wrong way. Just like Payday 2 there are special enemies in the way of tasers, cloakers, shields, bulldozers and snipers that spawn in frequently to stop you from getting your pay dirt. However unlike payday 2 the special enemies often act quite differently. For instance Bull dozers move much more faster than they do in payday 2, though they don't have as much health, still if you get shot twice from them its more often than not 'man down'. Tasers will often come in pairs and strike instantly. Cloakers have no  warning sound that they are close by and most of the time will pounce on you when your trying to interact with something or someone. Shields other than the Gl40, there is no other gun which can penetrate their shield. Forget your Gl40 and the only answer left is to quickly try and flank them. Snipers in the droves are undoubtedly the worst. Everytime I try the level undercover on 145+ I openly weep when I'm informed i have to go to the roof.

The second biggest difference between this and Payday 2 is that ALL the maps are LOUD. None of them are 'True' stealth. Granted 'Diamond Heist' can be done stealthily on the easier levels, but try it on 145+ and its all guns blazing again. Sadly the stealth side of things was never properly instituted in this version of payday and so playing as a pacifist would never be a real option most of the time. There are only 9 maps in total with four different difficulty settings with 145+ being the hardest. (This is not including the fact that someone has created a mod which creates a 193+ level for those that love to experience sheer pain).

The developers Overkill have finished with the game and have moved all their focus on Payday 2 even recreating the same levels from this one to there. So most people ask the obvious question, 'Why bother to play PAYDAY the Heist?'

1) For the experience. SInce both the skill tree and the special enemies react differently there is a much more rewarding experience in the level of difficulty fighting in comradery with three other team mates against the relentless sheer hell of countless waves in this one than you might experience in Payday 2. Since all capped 193 players have the same instruments at each others disposal its all about game play and team work. Have one person acting alone and its probably game over for the whole team. This game is so much harder, that ive actually seen people who have spent 5,000 hrs plus be taken out within seconds by a cloaker or a taser. Having said that the game also offers fewer enemies for those that try each map solo without bots. This has given rise to the gauntlet of challenges of die hard fans to attempt the fool hardy of attempt of showing off their skills as they venture alone. Here is an example of two professionals who have raised to that challenge...

https://youtu.be/R4MNDlzqRJk

https://youtu.be/KjExnQ5p4ME

2) The history of the Original secret vault and what gamers had to do to get there is a rich part of gaming history to attempt it yourself is a 'must do' for any serious gamer out there . Here is a video explaining it all in detail...

https://youtu.be/j7nFAURAGEM?list=PLv2Qcu6n6_mI9QeFdDv_xDSe5WL-6Pusl

So basically first you need to do all the heists on 145+ to get the golden mask. Then play the first world bank with three other people each wearing a golden mask standing in your respective positions, next you will have a 2hr constant onslaught of the hardest enemies  while you wait for the drill to get through. Only to be confronted by another room which requires a correct code to be entered into the floor tiles to avoid being gassed to death. Then you will get rewarded with one of the most beautiful vaults you will ever see. Some even claim that sending the video of the above the adventure to Overkill will result with you getting a special secret mask.

3) Another challenge I would recommend is the doing the last level 'No Mercy' Loud all the way on 145+, there are no achievments for this challenge, the reward is simply knowing the fact that you have done the hardest level, on the hardest difficulty, the hardest way.

The Payday Story stops abruptly and hints towards left for dead more than it does Payday 2. It honestly feels that something is missing like a payday 1.5 maybe?

True there are plenty of Trolls, Hackers and Noobs in this game just like there is in Payday 2. True there are only 9 levels to grind away at constantly reaching the coveted 193 level, but its the level of difficulty and the constant dedication of the professional players which remain behind throwing out challenges and helping new ones that can make this game a really rewarding experience and a thumbs up.

In final it is a great game to vent off some steam if you ever get a speeding fine, Thanks Overkill. Wish you were still here...

reviewText:
Go back to where it all began, with the 4 original heisters... Payday: The Heist. If you want a game that actually challenges you and focuses on team play, then grab this gem. With only 1 DLC ever made (excluding the in game soundtrack), this is a true video game, not a DLC fest, like Payday 2 has become.

This is a straightforward team based shooter with no strings attached and has some similiar game mechanics of Left 4 Dead. It is a game where you must work hard as a team or die as a team! It is an unforgiving game and the challenges become harder as you progress, until you get to the dreaded Overkill 145+ difficulty, which is much harder than the Deathwish on Payday 2.

In this game, you do not have Skills, Perk Decks, Armror or fancy weapons (RPGs) at your disposal. Because of the lack of these things, you will need to work hard and be smart with your team, to overcome the Overkill 145+ achievements.

The only negative is finding a team to play with. There is only a very small amount of people who play this (probably a maximum of 300 people online at any one time). But there is plenty Payday The Heist groups and of course the forum is still reasonably active. There will always be someone out there to help you, if you don't have friends to play with.

So what does this mean for you? Well, go Steal, Kill and make a Deal, in the best Payday game made.

Pros:
-Original concept, before it got ruined in Payday 2
-Very team focused game play
-Very challenging experience
-No DLC every month
-No micro-transactions
-No cross-overs (with game or film companies)
-No large downloads every month (2gigs or more, are standard updates in PD2)

Cons:
-Small amount of players (this can be over come by finding groups / forums to get a team)
-Game can lag a lot more than Payday 2 (especially if your team is from around the world)
-Some minor bugs in game, that will probably never be repaired

I give this game 4 out of 5 Beers.

Cheers,
Frost

reviewText:
The best co-op game out there which 4 friends (or 4 total strangers) can have a blast playing the role of a high profile carrier criminal.

If you like in-game eye candy over gameplay, play changing builds, crafting masks, modding guns this game isn't for you, check the other game.

General Info:

♠ Total of 9 heists to attempt, 7 from base game & 2 from Wolfpack DLC. Without the DLC you can still join lobbies running them but not be able to get few achievements tied with the 2 heists.
♠ 5 Difficulties, easy(1st 2 heists only), normal, hard, overkill, overkill145+ & new addition of overkill193 (modified overkill145+) from DorHUD*.

Pros:
1. Very high replay value.
2. Large heist areas, which you have ample space to run around.
3. Good untiring graphics
4. Nice sounds.
5. Competitive Steam Achievements & challenges to complete.

Cons: & some remedies
1. Cheaters -
Even though this is not a PvP game there are a lot of pathetic fks who want to ruin your game. There isn't any built-in cheat protection, so it's a good idea to do a quick Shift+Tab -> View Players" & check the stats of the players in the lobby. Having many abnormal heist finishing times
date:
having masks which shouldn't have (not always a cheater though) are some indicators a cheater in your lobby.

You may want to check out DorHUD* which will give you some useful information about players in your lobby & help you ban cheaters permanently.

2. Disconnects -
If it takes very long time to connect to the lobby there is a good chance you'll disconnect during the play.

3. Some rare bugs - like falling out of the map


*DorHUD http://steamcommunity.com/groups/dahm4pd

Get a 4 pack & gift to 3 good friends or go public find some good friends & have fun!"

reviewText:
PAYDAY: The Heist is a first-person shooter game developed by OVERKILL Software, the first of the PAYDAY game. First of all, DO NOT compare this game with PAYDAY 2, that game is newer than this and has been improved and upgraded a lot.

PAYDAY: The Heist lets you play as 4 criminal named Dallas, Hoxton, Wolf and Chains in their criminal career, executing heist from robbing a bank, street chase, into breaking a hospital for something. It's not as easy as blazing your way inside as sometimes you have to make an entrances by drilling or blowing while defending yourself against police and SWAT assault in their attempt to arrest you. As you play, you will level up and get upgrades for your characters and weapons. PAYDAY: The Heist also lets you play cooperatively up-to 4 players.

PAYDAY: The Heist has very decent graphics and effects. The Characters Dallas, Hoxton, Wolf and Chains has very great detail on them, and the police has many variant too which also affect the gameplay. The performances is also great, no problems at all, nothing broken.

If you compare PAYDAY: The Heist with PAYDAY 2, PAYDAY The Heist is a game before PAYDAY 2, like many games with a sequel, the sequel are supposed to be better than the previous right? So don't compare them.

Overall PAYDAY: The Heist is a good game, especially when you can play with your friends, 4 of them. It's harder to play this game alone in singleplayer, just try to find some friends or buy 4 pack. I recommend this.

Rating 9/10

reviewText:
PAYDAY The Heist is a 4-player co-op FPS game in which you and your friends heist your way to wealth and glory. with nine well designed heists(Two of them DLC) to keep you busy.

Somehow, it manages to be better than the sequel, Payday 2, with better and more balanced weaponry, better heists, better balanced hostiles and smooth, mostly intuitive controls. That said, it is not without flaws. The stealth system is not entirely as great as in Payday 2, but that's pretty much all I can think of at the moment.

The progression is decent, giving you new guns and abilities over time while giving you plenty of gametime to unlock it all. You can choose what general direction to unlock things in on leveling up, and things unlock at a steady pace that doesn't leave you grinding for levels just so you can play as you prefer. All in all, it's well made and works fine.

The gameplay itself is pretty good, with cover playing an important part and no enemy feeling unfair or like an unreasonable bulletsponge. It makes sure that almost every thing you're doing is of importance, with a good pace where sometimes it is tense and other times you can take a breather. It feels like you're always doing something, whether its rejoining your group, running from cover to cover, or taking out a few special units. Somehow the drill jams less than in Payday 2 as well.

Of course it's not all bad, the AI is just good enough to work, and the hordes of cops make you sometimes feel like you're playing L4D with cops instead of zombies, zombies with guns. There are surprisingly few negatives to Payday The Heist.

Overall, it's a bit old, but it's still great. I'd even say better than its sequel. And with regular sales it's easy to grab some friends and go heisting. If the regular price tag is not worth it to you, a sale will probably start soon.

reviewText:
TL:DR

Cons
- The Diesel engine is old, and while it doesn't yield its ugly veil as 'well' as it does in PD2, blemishes do present themselves
- No tutorial.   I always felt that a tutorial would greatly serve PD, introduce you more intimently with the enemies and Special units and their weaknesses.
-Hackers.  Are everywhere.  But if you are dying to find honest heisters, check out the Payday the Heist Online sub on Reddit!

Pros
-THIS GAME IS HARD.    And I love it.  While I feel its a shame it doesn't have a tutorial, this game pretty drops you directly in the frey and expects you figure it out.  It makes every heist a hard earned victory, and a vigorous one at that
-For whatever heisters remain, its generally a very supportive community
-A DLC expansion pack that is a true bang for your buck.  Hoenstly one of the best DLC packs I've ever bought
-Fantastic atmosphere!  Each of the heists stand out for a variety of reasons, and its easy to tell them aprt.

Verdict

It's 15 bucks.  You're not losing much, and its some of the most fun I've played online!


OVERDRAWN, SOAP BOX PREACHY SEGMENT:




Story Pretty much none.  Most of, if not all the missions you play in this game are extremely isolated and I like that, very much.  The base story is that you, and three of your friends are proffesional bank robbers taking on the biggest and most elaborate hits.  Ranging some simple bank heists, to raiding a panic room for cash, to even stealing blood from a patient in a hospital.  While the mission total is short, (With the games expansion pack only offering an additonal two) there can only be around 9 heists.  But the RNG makes for great staying power.

Mechanics/Engine
PAYDAY: The Heist is  of the two, one of the more grounded games.  It knows its engines limitations, and is sparing with the spectacles.  PAYDAY 2 on the other hand, is a much more... Outstanding game.  With PAYDAY: The Heist, you are only able to go loud for a majority of the missions, or heists.  Only one two can be stealthed, by not fully.  Working in horde based siege modes, there are four phases to a mission:

Casing: You and the crew are just casing the joint.  Taking in security previsions, placements and looking for objectives

Anticipation: The heist has just gone loud.  The police have just showed up, and it's about to go down.

Assault:The police will, in favor of tacticallly approching your arrest, will instead besiege the area with armed forces.  Overwhelimg your defensives, on the higher difficulty.  They have a tendancy to really throw down the gauntlet.
Control: This is the phase where the police pull a tactical withdrawl.  Though only briefly.  You use this time, to med-up and restock.  In certain cases, trade allies from custody.


Music
This is, where the PAYDAY series has always managed to impress.  The Soundtrack, compased by Simon Viklund, then Overkill's inhouse music producer and dialogue director, impresses as always with a booming soundtrack.  While the songs can not be interchanged, like in PD2, they are much more tied into the heist you're playing.

reviewText: Ah, Payday. I got the game while it was free and I'm glad I did. A fun game where you play as one of four members of a group which robs banks and conducts other similar heists. Playing with friends is highly recommended as you will either bask in glory when you all finish that perfect bank job or yell and curse at that one guy who won't help you back up. You start off with basic weapons and skills, but these are upgraded when heists are completed, objectives are achieved, et cetera. You will find yourself constantly replaying First World Bank because it's the only one where you have a chance of finishing, but the missions are also randomised a slightly different way each time you play them.\n\nIf you consider buying this game but end up going for Payday 2 instead, try and get this during a sale. The assault waves in Payday 2 are still strong, but it always seems like the cops never leave you alone in this. If you get to a stage where you find Payday 2 is too easy for you, come to this. It is still a very fun and challenging game with friends and that is what keeps me playing it.

reviewText: In Payday: The Heist, players use a variety of firearms to complete objectives (usually centered around stealing a certain object, person, or a particular amount of money). The game plays from the first person perspective, but offers a few twists on the standard FPS formula. Killing civilians is punished, instead players may take a limited number as hostages. Should any player get arrested (after taking enough damage and not being 'revived' in time) during the heist, one of his teammates may release a hostage, allowing a trade to take place which allows a single player to be released. While playing the levels, players will notice a lot of variation in a single level, as there are often a large number of random events programmed in. An example of this is the location of the bank manager in First World Bank.\n\nThe game focuses on four robbers (Dallas, Hoxton, Chains, and Wolf) who team up. Their first heist took place at the First World Bank, where they entered a vault by using thermite hidden on the inside of a photocopier and stole a large amount of money. A post-game message congratulates the group, telling them that they are set for life"
recommended: including robbing drug junkies in an abandoned apartment complex and ambushing a prisoner transport in heavy rain weather
hoursPlayed: simply for the enjoyment of the players."

reviewText:
My review for Payday: The Heist

Payday: The Heist is a fun CO-OP game, where you play with your friends or strangers in different types of missions from robbing a bank to helping a criminal escape, The game focuses more on action than stealth like your typical heist movies, so if you like games that are more of a bank robbing simulator (or you just definitely want to feel like a badass robber) and pure action and that feeling you're in a heist movie then this game is definitely for you.

There is also a sequel called Payday 2, If you're a fan of a hybrid of Loud/action and Stealth, then buy the sequel.

reviewText:
Point Break meets Left 4 Dead.

A refreshingly original IP. Fun to play solo; made better in co-op with friends.

Each heist offers a unique mission, however with only a handful of heists the game demands a fair amount of repetition while the player learns the scenarios, increases their character's strength, and hones skills.

Early levels can be off-putting due to the ineffectiveness of the characters' abilities - especially solo - but worth persevering with for the gratification of later levels, as the heists start to become too easy and it's time to increase the difficulty settings.

- Skinny from the Fat B*stard (curator link)

reviewText:
So, this is a COOP game from 2011, but since half of these reviews are slow as ♥♥♥♥, I decided to come back and reveal yet another game from the dephts of the past years. I present to you, PAYDAY: The Heist.

This game is ♥♥♥♥ ass fun with friends, and not that good when playing solo. PAYDAY: The Heist's synopsis involves 4 professional guys robbing picked out heists. When I first started this game, I was given the benefit of the doubt in thinking that this will be some crappy indie game, even more doubt when I found out the company, Overkill Software, was formed from the directors of GRIN, whom is responsible for one of the worst, most generic games ever made, EVER. I was wrong.

GRAPHICS

Now, the game doesn't have those top-notch graphics we see, it ponders more to the gameplay, but this section isn't left out. Everything, from the First World Bank, to the No Mercy hospital is enriched in detail, and complexity. Low-res textures are, as much as they can, removed and only when you are some detail-nut who likes to notice things. The game doesn't offer that much of a linear chance, but everything is complex and well-made. There are also some visual filter stuff in the menu I don't use. Bloom ♥♥♥♥, while appearing at some points of a heist, is not excessive and appears only for added realism. All-in all, graphics are pretty good.

SOUND

The sounds, while not perfectly executed, give some needed environments the buff they need. Civilians screaming in terror are probably the most thought out, but the guns don't sound great. For example, the cops shooting their pistol sounds pretty ♥♥♥♥ing weak. And when huge firefights occur, the gun sounds just take a huge ♥♥♥♥ and leave, because everything is just said gun sounds, no bullets whizzings or anything. Doesn't give that much of a scenery if you ask me. The music makes up for it though. It's a mix of rock and electronic, and gives you that adrenaline pump when you need it. Bass rapes the songs at times, but it's still executed to pump you even more.

GAMEPLAY

Now here is the best part of the game. It really gives it it's substance. You and your buddies go on heists that are picked for you. Prediction is eliminated at this point, because every situation occurs RANDOMLY, and requires you and your team to pick out your loadouts carefully. At the start, you are bestowned with the option to scout out ahead and mark out the plan, which doesn't give the game that immediate action build like the mainstream concurence now-a-days. The only drawback I have on this heisting system is how unreal it is. Seriously, you get like 5000 SWAT officers shoved up your ♥♥♥. WHERE the ♥♥♥♥ do they find this kind of firepower? I am drilling the vault, and a great bunch of police officers appear at an Assault wave ready to buttrape you. Of course, this is all for an intended challenge, but really? You're gonna bring the whole America down on my ♥♥♥? Once you start the heist, you can use the F key to shout at stupid ♥♥♥ civilians who don't listen to you. They also managed to sucessfully find some use out of the keyboard key. You can use that to make officers cuff themselves, mark out special units, and do a ♥♥♥♥♥on of other things. It's amazing how much use one button can do here. Most of the gameplay involves drills and saws that are required, so it may get tedious for you, but the replayability and different scenarios excuse for it it, and gives it more interest the more you play. The A.I, unfortunatley, sucks balls when you play solo, but it can be perfectly understood because this is a CO-OP game and not designed only for you (if in that case you have no friends, ♥♥♥♥♥♥). The game also warrants defending your backs. If you go alone to find some object or ♥♥♥♥, you can guarantee you'll be in custody, unless you're pretty sure you can handle the cops. It's all about thinking and planning everything out as a team. You get a HUGE arsenal for things to prep yourself up too. Silenced UZIs, pistols, 2 shotguns, assault rifles and so much more. If you're a gun-nut, you'll love it. I had some added problems with the difficulties, because it's just police spam all around, and basically redefines the whole meaning of difficult. You need to SERIOUSLY prep up and have some firepower to finish a mission on the highest difficulty. This difficulty is somewhat lowered when the music from earlier kicks in during an Assault wave for adrenaline, and also the added cash, to remind your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥ that you have a million bucks waiting for you to roll in.

STORY

There is no story for the game, but it has a synopsis. Basically, 4 guys (a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, a Sheffield guy, American and a Swedish) gather around and eventually meet some hacker/whatever called Bain. From then on, it's straight heisting. My favourite guy is Hoxton, the British ♥♥♥♥.

This game is what CO-OP should be. While it has some drawbacks, I had kickass time playing it, so I give it an:

8.5/10",March 10"

reviewText:
PROs:
-Guns feel solid. While the starting stuff can feel a tiny bit weak at first, after getting some upgrades the weapons start to fill out nicely.
-Difficult. Its kind of arguable, I suppose, that being difficult is a good thing, but its hard to feel like a winner without having to first travel down the bloodiest, most bullet-filled hell that the higher difficulties on this game can be.
-Graphics aren't too bad; that's always a plus. Don't expect anything mind numbing on this front however.
-Soundtrack is noice. There can never be enough beep-boops in my game music.
-Teamwork is key. Also pretty arugable to be a pro, but there is nothing better in my opinion then completely curbstomping a giant wave of enemies with all of your friends (given that you are good enough).

CONs:
-The difficulty might push away people who just want a casual experience. Its pretty hard to be casual when its so easy to get downed. Break from cover without thinking on the higher difficulties? Dead. Not taking out Snipers? They will find a way to shoot you eventually. Bulldozer charging you from behind? Good luck with that.
-PhysX installer bothers you as you boot up the game. This is fixable, however; just follow this guide: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=281979578

Basically, I would suggest this game to anyone looking for a difficult experience that rewards you greatly for working as a team, doing objectives, and surviving the hordes of cops that come at you. Just make sure you bring a ♥♥♥♥ ton of ammo and doctor bags and you are gonna have a good time.

So, this is a COOP game from 2011, but since half of these reviews are slow as ♥♥♥♥, I decided to come back and reveal yet another game from the dephts of the past years. I present to you, PAYDAY: The Heist.

This game is ♥♥♥♥ ass fun with friends, and not that good when playing solo. PAYDAY: The Heist's synopsis involves 4 professional guys robbing picked out heists. When I first started this game, I was given the benefit of the doubt in thinking that this will be some crappy indie game, even more doubt when I found out the company, Overkill Software, was formed from the directors of GRIN, whom is responsible for one of the worst, most generic games ever made, EVER. I was wrong.

GRAPHICS

Now, the game doesn't have those top-notch graphics we see, it ponders more to the gameplay, but this section isn't left out. Everything, from the First World Bank, to the No Mercy hospital is enriched in detail, and complexity. Low-res textures are, as much as they can, removed and only when you are some detail-nut who likes to notice things. The game doesn't offer that much of a linear chance, but everything is complex and well-made. There are also some visual filter stuff in the menu I don't use. Bloom ♥♥♥♥, while appearing at some points of a heist, is not excessive and appears only for added realism. All-in all, graphics are pretty good.

SOUND

The sounds, while not perfectly executed, give some needed environments the buff they need. Civilians screaming in terror are probably the most thought out, but the guns don't sound great. For example, the cops shooting their pistol sounds pretty ♥♥♥♥ing weak. And when huge firefights occur, the gun sounds just take a huge ♥♥♥♥ and leave, because everything is just said gun sounds, no bullets whizzings or anything. Doesn't give that much of a scenery if you ask me. The music makes up for it though. It's a mix of rock and electronic, and gives you that adrenaline pump when you need it. Bass rapes the songs at times, but it's still executed to pump you even more.

GAMEPLAY

Now here is the best part of the game. It really gives it it's substance. You and your buddies go on heists that are picked for you. Prediction is eliminated at this point, because every situation occurs RANDOMLY, and requires you and your team to pick out your loadouts carefully. At the start, you are bestowned with the option to scout out ahead and mark out the plan, which doesn't give the game that immediate action build like the mainstream concurence now-a-days. The only drawback I have on this heisting system is how unreal it is. Seriously, you get like 5000 SWAT officers shoved up your ♥♥♥. WHERE the ♥♥♥♥ do they find this kind of firepower? I am drilling the vault, and a great bunch of police officers appear at an Assault wave ready to buttrape you. Of course, this is all for an intended challenge, but really? You're gonna bring the whole America down on my ♥♥♥? Once you start the heist, you can use the F key to shout at stupid ♥♥♥ civilians who don't listen to you. They also managed to sucessfully find some use out of the keyboard key. You can use that to make officers cuff themselves, mark out special units, and do a ♥♥♥♥♥on of other things. It's amazing how much use one button can do here. Most of the gameplay involves drills and saws that are required, so it may get tedious for you, but the replayability and different scenarios excuse for it it, and gives it more interest the more you play. The A.I, unfortunatley, sucks balls when you play solo, but it can be perfectly understood because this is a CO-OP game and not designed only for you (if in that case you have no friends, ♥♥♥♥♥♥). The game also warrants defending your backs. If you go alone to find some object or ♥♥♥♥, you can guarantee you'll be in custody, unless you're pretty sure you can handle the cops. It's all about thinking and planning everything out as a team. You get a HUGE arsenal for things to prep yourself up too. Silenced UZIs, pistols, 2 shotguns, assault rifles and so much more. If you're a gun-nut, you'll love it. I had some added problems with the difficulties, because it's just police spam all around, and basically redefines the whole meaning of difficult. You need to SERIOUSLY prep up and have some firepower to finish a mission on the highest difficulty. This difficulty is somewhat lowered when the music from earlier kicks in during an Assault wave for adrenaline, and also the added cash, to remind your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥ that you have a million bucks waiting for you to roll in.

STORY

There is no story for the game, but it has a synopsis. Basically, 4 guys (a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, a Sheffield guy, American and a Swedish) gather around and eventually meet some hacker/whatever called Bain. From then on, it's straight heisting. My favourite guy is Hoxton, the British ♥♥♥♥.

This game is what CO-OP should be. While it has some drawbacks, I had kickass time playing it, so I give it an:

8.5/10",March 10"

reviewText:
PROs:
-Guns feel solid. While the starting stuff can feel a tiny bit weak at first, after getting some upgrades the weapons start to fill out nicely.
-Difficult. Its kind of arguable, I suppose, that being difficult is a good thing, but its hard to feel like a winner without having to first travel down the bloodiest, most bullet-filled hell that the higher difficulties on this game can be.
-Graphics aren't too bad; that's always a plus. Don't expect anything mind numbing on this front however.
-Soundtrack is noice. There can never be enough beep-boops in my game music.
-Teamwork is key. Also pretty arugable to be a pro, but there is nothing better in my opinion then completely curbstomping a giant wave of enemies with all of your friends (given that you are good enough).

CONs:
-The difficulty might push away people who just want a casual experience. Its pretty hard to be casual when its so easy to get downed. Break from cover without thinking on the higher difficulties? Dead. Not taking out Snipers? They will find a way to shoot you eventually. Bulldozer charging you from behind? Good luck with that.
-PhysX installer bothers you as you boot up the game. This is fixable, however; just follow this guide: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=281979578

Basically, I would suggest this game to anyone looking for a difficult experience that rewards you greatly for working as a team, doing objectives, and surviving the hordes of cops that come at you. Just make sure you bring a ♥♥♥♥ ton of ammo and doctor bags and you are gonna have a good time.

reviewText:
This game takes place in an accountant's office.

A poor, Swedish family struggles to pay bills and survive with it's miniscule income.

You take the roll of the accountant. You must manage the budget, and ultimately win the game by keeping the family's bills paid, and everyone alive. Moving them from one payday to another payday.

When the father loses his job as a chef, he gets quite furious. The game spices things up by making you work under heavy conditions, such as an unemployed Swedish chef screaming Bork de bork bork." at you while you try to crunch numbers.

It's truly the Creme Egg of video games.

1/10. Would bork again."

reviewText:
Status: Approved (Get it, but on sale)

What is Payday The Heist?
Well, it's a 4 player coop game. To put it short it's probably a wave based FPS. Mostly, players will try to hold ground and hold off the police till the objective gets done to progress futher. Other then that some heist have multiple objectives to guard, thus leaving one behind to defend it. There are times when you need to get something fixed, so one player has to go and do that etc. Plus the game also has items that players can equip and share like medic bags, ammo. Well, it certainly does good at coop, that i can say.

The original game consists of 6 heists. Unlike Payday 2 or The Wolf's DLC, the original game's heists don't offer much variety, so you can't really go stealthy and all. One mission has stealth, but it's partial and too linear in my opinion. Overkill also added an extra free mission - No Mercy.
ps: No Mercy & The Wolf DLC are basically the foundation of Payday 2. They have dynamic events, so probably the next time you play them, them may have the safe in a different place, the items(like wooden logs) in random places etc. Though there is a slight difference with Payday 2's, they had those events, where some random event could happen, like you would go into a safe and it will be full of C4, it won't always happen unlike in Payday 2.

The game has 3 special enemies: Bulldozer, Tazer and Cloaker. It also have cops with shields and standard cops(their armor depends on the difficulty level). They will require different tactics to be used against them, making a more exciting gameplay. The game has armor and health: armor outlines your characters avatar in bottom right, and it can regenerate, health on the other hand can't. When you get 0 health you will be put into bleedout(last stand), either you will get put into custody or get saved by your teammates. Your teammates can also trade you for a hostage.

The game also has great unique atmosphere. Like come on, how many games let you rob banks, yet  can really give your that feeling. The game even has different masks to choose from. You can tie up hostages, and trade them. And of course you can interact with MONEY.

I want to address one big issue though
The amount of content. The base game has only 7 heist, and a very small amounts of guns, other then that, it has 145 level, and damn, it's very tedious, yet offering a very small amount of rewards.
Because of that i suggest most people to purchase it on a sale. Though i suggest you to get the Wolf DLC , which gives you 2 heists and a new set of weapons.(it's really worth it)

One thing i want to breakdown to you, is the leveling up system.
There are 145 levels and 3 upgrade trees, each has 48 unlocks(48x3=144), and after you unlock them all you get the 49th unlock(#145)
Each time you level up you get an unlock in the tree that you had chosen
You choose the upgrade tree during the mission, by holding down Tab" and pressing [1]
recommended: or [3]\nThe DLC adds another upgrade tree
hoursPlayed: increasing the level cap from 145 to 193(48 unlocks). To upgrade it's tree you do the same as for the above."

reviewText:
Imagine the perfect robbery: you know the blueprints inside out, when the guards go for their coffee breaks, and exactly how to get into the safe. Everything goes without a hitch, and by the time the safe is found, you're laughing. Not a shot fired. Payday: The Heist doesn't work like that.

Despite the crime-caper presentation, tactical objectives and elaborate plans, Payday always comes down to shooting. Four players go into a situation - a bank with a vault full of juicy gold in the basement, an ambush to rescue a prisoner from a police convoy - and then get into a hell of a big fight with the police. It's a magpie co-op shooter, most obviously influenced by Left 4 Dead's dynamic approach to the team-based FPS and Modern Warfare's Spec Ops mode, and its developers are clearly students of the mass of 'horde' modes out there.

Payday has faults, but is very good indeed, an FPS where common elements are carefully made to fit its rhythm rather than just taken for granted: this sounds like faint praise, but it has the best ammo balancing I've seen in a long time. Players start fully-stocked and a perk can give bigger starting clips, but from that point every bullet has to be maximised. Enemies drop small amounts of ammo, but only enough to keep your head above water.

Health is equally well-handled, a mixture of an overall bar that only recharges in segments and a 'shield' that recharges wholly. The more the overall bar goes down, the faster the player is knocked down, making it a treasure to be guarded: a backup that in clutch moments gives that extra second of life.

You're always on a knife-edge. A healthy team can feel invincible, but a team that's been banged up is too brittle to fight carelessly. One-time deployables can be taken into missions, and using them wisely is a whole other story.

On top of such considered engineering, Payday boasts a winning art style that mixes grotesque clown masks with sharp suits and a brutishly high-tech take on law enforcement. Even more impressive - stunning, even - is the dynamic audio design, which contributes to all of Payday's most exhilarating moments. One level will have a tight, looping drum beat that builds and builds into a pounding house tune just as all hell is breaking loose; another will begin with a cheesy piece of europop that turns into an industrial wail of sirens. It has an absolute gift for catching the right moment to push itself to the front and centre of the experience, and burrows its way into your mindset. When the sound's going crazy, so are you.

The cops are a motley bunch at the start of a mission, wearing their short-sleeved blue shirts and little caps and dying in droves. As things pick up, more capable classes start mixing into the waves: machine-gunners with light body armour, shotgunners in thick riot gear and special agents that sneak around before emptying a revolver into your back. Individually, they don't amount to much and neither does the AI, but you'll only ever see them in swarming groups that seem to come from nowhere, relentlessly battering a fixed position or skewering a moving group.

Payday's mission structure is basically 'quiet time' and then 'assault', with much more of the latter. Each of its setups has mission objectives to be completed in the middle of the shooting, but every single one involves holding down a button at a certain point then waiting for a timer to tick down. Heat it ain't, but things are kept interesting by the objectives changing position and sequence on each playthrough - a structure that comes to fruition in Diamond Heist. (More on that later.)

There are always small groups of cops around, but every few minutes the game sends a heavily-telegraphed wave of enemies in, which puts the game in 'Assault' mode. These relentless firefights can last from a few minutes to what feels like an eternity, but is probably more like 15 minutes - and during it, hundreds and hundreds of cops will die. They pour out of corridors, scale balconies, drop from helicopters, bust down doors, explode out of lift shafts - and if they get position on your team, the crossfire is withering.

The final twist in every assault wave is the special cops. They're half Left 4 Dead's special infected, half Modern Warfare 2's riot shields and Juggernauts - but at least they're good copies. The taser cop immobilises players with unerring accuracy, making them spasm and empty their gun's clip wildly until a team-mate intervenes or they go down. The Bulldozer's a giant that can take sustained punishment and mete it out, a terrifying sight when you're in a corner, and shield-toting cops make a slower but no less inexorable advance on your position, begging you to waste bullets. Cloakers are the one original nasty: pinpoint spec-ops soldiers that specialise in sneaking up or rushing in for a deadly melee attack and then picking off your buddies when they wander in to save the day.

The police have a lot of options and there's no telling exactly what an assault wave will contain - some wars are won at a distance with calm precision and some with a shotgun in the face. Payday only offers six missions, and some of those aren't huge, but the ebb and flow of its assault waves means it just about gets away with it - even in the same environment, with the same starting positions, no two waves play out alike.

Payday does have one recurring problem: its downtime is often too long. There will be times when, one minute after surviving a pitched battle, you're waiting on a roof for the next event to be triggered or the next police attack - and nothing happens. Payday's best moments are when it stitches its discrete chunks together seamlessly, moving from dynamic objectives into assault waves into brief respites. But every so often, it just leaves you hanging.

There are other flat notes. Civilians can be tied up to use as hostages - these can be traded between rounds for any team member who's gone down permanently, and cause the police to start sending in rescue squads. The mechanic fills a role capably enough but feels a little under-developed: being able to use hostages as bargaining chips or human shields during assaults, for example, would seem obvious.

Payday doesn't even go that deep, and to be fair it shows little desire to. But there are infuriating inconsistencies within its world. You must avoid killing civilians, for example, in the midst of these slaughterfests - but these civilians are so nakedly designed to keep on running into crossfire that hitting one feels like the game's pulled a trick on you.

There are plenty more moments of silliness, but Payday gets it right, too: sawing through bars and burning through vault roofs with thermite are the stuff blueprints are made of. And then there's the Diamond Heist.

In terms of robber fantasies, there are few better setups than a high-security vault filled with diamonds on the top floor of a skyscraper, slap bang in the middle of a party. Only available on Hard difficulty, Diamond Heist is easily Payday's most dynamic and varied mission, with major branches opening up differently on each play-through, and it's set in a quite brilliant environment.

The vault's in the middle, and several balcony floors rise around it full of offices and cubbyholes. Staircases lead to a huge roof with a helipad and glass skylights. The mission can be completed entirely through stealth, the four players moving silently from floor to floor disabling alarms and avoiding security patrols, before a clean getaway without a shot fired. This didn't happen a single time that I was involved.

Rating: 10/10

reviewText:
Imagine the perfect robbery: you know the blueprints inside out, when the guards go for their coffee breaks, and exactly how to get into the safe. Everything goes without a hitch, and by the time the safe is found, you're laughing. Not a shot fired. Payday: The Heist doesn't work like that.

Despite the crime-caper presentation, tactical objectives and elaborate plans, Payday always comes down to shooting. Four players go into a situation - a bank with a vault full of juicy gold in the basement, an ambush to rescue a prisoner from a police convoy - and then get into a hell of a big fight with the police. It's a magpie co-op shooter, most obviously influenced by Left 4 Dead's dynamic approach to the team-based FPS and Modern Warfare's Spec Ops mode, and its developers are clearly students of the mass of 'horde' modes out there.

Payday has faults, but is very good indeed, an FPS where common elements are carefully made to fit its rhythm rather than just taken for granted: this sounds like faint praise, but it has the best ammo balancing I've seen in a long time. Players start fully-stocked and a perk can give bigger starting clips, but from that point every bullet has to be maximised. Enemies drop small amounts of ammo, but only enough to keep your head above water.

Health is equally well-handled, a mixture of an overall bar that only recharges in segments and a 'shield' that recharges wholly. The more the overall bar goes down, the faster the player is knocked down, making it a treasure to be guarded: a backup that in clutch moments gives that extra second of life.

You're always on a knife-edge. A healthy team can feel invincible, but a team that's been banged up is too brittle to fight carelessly. One-time deployables can be taken into missions, and using them wisely is a whole other story.

On top of such considered engineering, Payday boasts a winning art style that mixes grotesque clown masks with sharp suits and a brutishly high-tech take on law enforcement. Even more impressive - stunning, even - is the dynamic audio design, which contributes to all of Payday's most exhilarating moments. One level will have a tight, looping drum beat that builds and builds into a pounding house tune just as all hell is breaking loose; another will begin with a cheesy piece of europop that turns into an industrial wail of sirens. It has an absolute gift for catching the right moment to push itself to the front and centre of the experience, and burrows its way into your mindset. When the sound's going crazy, so are you.

The cops are a motley bunch at the start of a mission, wearing their short-sleeved blue shirts and little caps and dying in droves. As things pick up, more capable classes start mixing into the waves: machine-gunners with light body armour, shotgunners in thick riot gear and special agents that sneak around before emptying a revolver into your back. Individually, they don't amount to much and neither does the AI, but you'll only ever see them in swarming groups that seem to come from nowhere, relentlessly battering a fixed position or skewering a moving group.

Payday's mission structure is basically 'quiet time' and then 'assault', with much more of the latter. Each of its setups has mission objectives to be completed in the middle of the shooting, but every single one involves holding down a button at a certain point then waiting for a timer to tick down. Heat it ain't, but things are kept interesting by the objectives changing position and sequence on each playthrough - a structure that comes to fruition in Diamond Heist. (More on that later.)

There are always small groups of cops around, but every few minutes the game sends a heavily-telegraphed wave of enemies in, which puts the game in 'Assault' mode. These relentless firefights can last from a few minutes to what feels like an eternity, but is probably more like 15 minutes - and during it, hundreds and hundreds of cops will die. They pour out of corridors, scale balconies, drop from helicopters, bust down doors, explode out of lift shafts - and if they get position on your team, the crossfire is withering.

The final twist in every assault wave is the special cops. They're half Left 4 Dead's special infected, half Modern Warfare 2's riot shields and Juggernauts - but at least they're good copies. The taser cop immobilises players with unerring accuracy, making them spasm and empty their gun's clip wildly until a team-mate intervenes or they go down. The Bulldozer's a giant that can take sustained punishment and mete it out, a terrifying sight when you're in a corner, and shield-toting cops make a slower but no less inexorable advance on your position, begging you to waste bullets. Cloakers are the one original nasty: pinpoint spec-ops soldiers that specialise in sneaking up or rushing in for a deadly melee attack and then picking off your buddies when they wander in to save the day.

The police have a lot of options and there's no telling exactly what an assault wave will contain - some wars are won at a distance with calm precision and some with a shotgun in the face. Payday only offers six missions, and some of those aren't huge, but the ebb and flow of its assault waves means it just about gets away with it - even in the same environment, with the same starting positions, no two waves play out alike.

Payday does have one recurring problem: its downtime is often too long. There will be times when, one minute after surviving a pitched battle, you're waiting on a roof for the next event to be triggered or the next police attack - and nothing happens. Payday's best moments are when it stitches its discrete chunks together seamlessly, moving from dynamic objectives into assault waves into brief respites. But every so often, it just leaves you hanging.

There are other flat notes. Civilians can be tied up to use as hostages - these can be traded between rounds for any team member who's gone down permanently, and cause the police to start sending in rescue squads. The mechanic fills a role capably enough but feels a little under-developed: being able to use hostages as bargaining chips or human shields during assaults, for example, would seem obvious.

Payday doesn't even go that deep, and to be fair it shows little desire to. But there are infuriating inconsistencies within its world. You must avoid killing civilians, for example, in the midst of these slaughterfests - but these civilians are so nakedly designed to keep on running into crossfire that hitting one feels like the game's pulled a trick on you.

There are plenty more moments of silliness, but Payday gets it right, too: sawing through bars and burning through vault roofs with thermite are the stuff blueprints are made of. And then there's the Diamond Heist.

In terms of robber fantasies, there are few better setups than a high-security vault filled with diamonds on the top floor of a skyscraper, slap bang in the middle of a party. Only available on Hard difficulty, Diamond Heist is easily Payday's most dynamic and varied mission, with major branches opening up differently on each play-through, and it's set in a quite brilliant environment.

The vault's in the middle, and several balcony floors rise around it full of offices and cubbyholes. Staircases lead to a huge roof with a helipad and glass skylights. The mission can be completed entirely through stealth, the four players moving silently from floor to floor disabling alarms and avoiding security patrols, before a clean getaway without a shot fired. This didn't happen a single time that I was involved.

Rating: 10/10

reviewText: Payday is an amazingly fun game. I like how simple, independent games like these always manage to get me to sink many more hours into it than any of the higher budget titles that are out. Unlike most shooters out, Payday forces you to play realistically. Your goal is not to rack up a body count, but to perform a heist. Rough around the edges, short in length, and aiming takes some time to get use to. However, in it's own way, it is very innovative. Each stage (lasting roughly 25-35 minutes) boasts with new surprises and situations depending on how you play and who you play with. No run through of any stage is ever the same. The stylish gameplay, cool concepts, and massive amounts of variety within it's few stages will keep players coming back for a very long time.

reviewText:
I bought this game on sale after I had so much fun playing PAYDAY 2, just to see how much PAYDAY 2 changed from PAYDAY: The Heist. I was surprised to find out they are like 2 completely different games!

ABOUT THE GAME:Take on the role of a hardened career criminal executing intense, dynamic heists in constant pursuit of the next “big score”

PROS: + Fantastic level design (completely different missions unlike PD2)
+ Vast variety of enemy types (cloakers, tasers, shields, dozers, its amazing)
+ Can be very challenging and engaging (requires teamwork)
+ Unique gameplay mechanics (taking hostages, restarting drills etc)
+ Skills and equipment are cool (a little bit lacking of content)

CONS: - You can't skip the opening cutscenes (makes repeating missions tedious)
- Only a few missions (can make the game feel repetitive)
- Interaction times are off (even with skills, restarting drill takes FOREVER)
- Stealth mechanics suck (not really much to work with)
- Connection problems (they happen often)

SUMMARY: The game is a lot more simple than its predecessor PAYDAY 2, but it is still just as fun in it's on way. It is much more loud oriented and doesn't have much stealth in it, but makes working with your teammates to complete tough missions more satisfying.

Final Grade:7 / 10 jammed drills

reviewText:
My crew and I have entered the bank and scoped the place out.
Two of them find the bank manager, who has the keycard that we need;
while I wait in queue at the tellers, and another teammate is upstairs with a
view of the whole room.

PRO:+ As a nice touch, killing civilians is a big no-no
+ Your respawn timer is longer for each civilian you’ve killed.
+ There are even some special police that require you to work together(co-op) to take down.
+ Upgrades opening up as you gain reputation levels by collecting money
+ It's even fun when you fail a mission and have to strategize with your team to figure out how to do better next time.
+ Payday has some of the best music at the start and end of its heists that I’ve heard in a while.

CONTRA- A major lack of communication
- I had to use a Steam Forum to find out how upgrade system works
- During the heists, there are a lot of objectives where you have to wait for something, but the game doesn’t always tell you how long you have to wait for.

CONCLUSION:Stealing stuff has never felt this cool.

reviewText:
PAYDAY: The Heist is a 4 player cooperative game which involves a crew of professional criminals attempting to score big by stealing various targeted items of high value. From cliche bank vaults to money printing plates, you can be sure that the local law enforcement won't make it easy for you and your crew getting out with the loot. Literally dozens of law enforcers will be dispatched to bring justice to stop your little crew from leaving the scene handcuff-free or alive.

Everyone should jump at the chance to get this underrated title. Helluva rewarding game with intense gameplay with heavy cooperative elements aswell. Extra content for this game is already in the works to keep it alive. If you need a great 4 player co-op game for you and your mates to enjoy, look no further. Especially with it's cheap $20 price tag and more discounts to come, it's a steal!
